Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Improving MRI Guided Thermal Therapies by Designed Magnetic Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project involves the creation of particles that will allow one to see a map of temperature within a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) measurement. This is a significant advancement because conventional thermometry is usually invasive, allows only single point temperature measurements, and may interfere with the therapeutic and imaging instrument. The proposed technology is designed to be biocompatible and minimally invasive, leading to fast 3D temperature mapping deep in the human body. The proposed materials and techniques can be used with MRI-guided thermal procedures which can replace scalpel-based surgery for a variety of cancers, improving patient outcomes and reducing surgical time. The method can also be used to improve treatments for essential tremor, uterine fibrosis and arteriovenous malformation. In these treatments, the temperature in the entire affected region must be constantly monitored. Due to the limitations of the currently used temperature measurement methods, these minimally invasive MRI-guided procedures are not frequently used or take considerably longer time than desired because surgeons often must work around failed temperature measurements. The work in this proposal could transform current methods of MRI-guided thermometry, significantly reducing surgery time and cost as well as improving patient outcomes.

This proposal develops a novel, minimally-invasive method of creating temperature maps superimposed on anatomical MRI images. The technology uses a new type of temperature-sensitive sensor, in the form of magnetic nanoparticles, and could ultimately be used within human or other tissues. The key idea is that magnetic particles embedded in tissue will create a local dipole magnetic field that will modulate (statically or dynamically) the homogeneity of the main static magnetic field of the MRI scanner. This changes the nuclear relaxation times of the tissue and broadens the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) linewidth, ultimately leading to local changes in the brightness of the MRI image. The magnetization of the particles is engineered to change with temperature, and therefore the results are temperature dependent. Different shades of gray in the weighted gradient echo MR images, can then be calibrated to obtain a spatial map of temperature. This has immediate application in providing real-time temperature information to the surgeon during MRI-guided thermal interventional procedures to treat cancer, for example. These new contrast sensors can operate in a wide temperature range both below and above the human body temperature, producing spatial maps of temperature with an accuracy better than 1 degree Celsius.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit and Broader Impact

Temperature monitoring is a critical element in rapidly developing methods of minimally invasive magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) guided thermal surgeries. Killing cancer tumors through laser ablations (heating) and cryoablations (freezing) are new kinds of therapeutic treatments with dramatically reduced side effects. In such procedures, temperature monitoring is necessary to effectively kill a tumor and simultaneously protect healthy tissue from overexposure to heat or freezing.

Currently, the standard method used for temperature monitoring in MRI, the proton resonance frequency (PRF) shift, does not provide reliable information in the presence of fatty tissue, magnetic field inhomogeneities, and tissue motion. Furthermore, PRF fails completely below the water freezing point during cryoablations. This is because the NMR linewidth of ice increases dramatically, making cryoablation frozen tissue simply black in MRI.

In Phase I of this project, we investigated if the brightness of an MRI image of tissue with embedded magnetic particles can be used as an indicator of local temperature.  We also discovered that certain polymers could be used as effective thermometers in MRI images. We explored the usefulness of this novel technology for MRI thermometry to improve the safety and efficiency of MRI guided thermal surgeries.

Project Outcomes

We determined that small magnetic particles, with a significant drop in magnetization as a function of temperature, are essential in obtaining temperature sensitive materials suitable for MRI thermometry.

In particular, doped iron-oxide nano-particles approximately 10 nm in size provide excellent temperature-sensitive contrast in MRI images and are suitable for temperature determination. If embedded in tissue mimicking aqueous gels, they produce bright contrast allowing for a 3 oC temperature change determination at a 3 mm distance. Our results also showed that for reasonable concentrations that our particles did not exhibit cytotoxicity.

During our studies on the method of encasing magnetic particles in biocompatible materials, we found that certain polymers have a significant change in their nuclear relaxation times with temperature, both above and below 0 oC. These polymers are also characterized by high density of protons, delivering bright MRI images. Hence, we explored the possibility of using such materials as temperature indicators during thermal ablations. We showed that these materials have a significant change in their MRI image brightness as a function of temperature.

We believe that the discovery of polymers that can serve as temperature indicators, both with and without embedded nanoparticles, is the most important outcome from Phase I of this project for the following reasons:

a) We have experimental evidence that the polymer method can work at temperatures ranging from ‑65 oC to +65 oC.

b) The method will be particularly helpful for low temperature cryoablations because there is currently no competing method that can be used in clinical settings for these measurements in MRI. 

c) Some polymer materials have a change in MRI brightness due to an intrinsic decrease of nuclear relaxation times with decreasing temperature, simplifying the preparation and offering additional options for temperature measurement.  The figure shows an example of a low temperature MR image of a silicone phantom obtained with an 11 oC temperature gradient between the blue and red circles. Note the drastic change in brightness; the colder parts of the phantom are brighter while warmer sections are darker. We estimate that a 3 oC temperature change can be determined within a distance of 3 mm.

d) We filed a provisional patent application entitled, ?Temperature Measurement Systems and Methods Using Magnetic Resonance Imaging?, number 63/075,668for the protection of the intellectual property developed during Phase I of this project.

We have made a number of important steps forward on commercialization as well.  First, our polymer materials are similar to those already approved by the FDA for use in the human body, significantly reducing the time and cost for any regulatory process. Second, we continued to look for commercial applications and partners related to our research.  Among the most successful of our outreach efforts was an ongoing connection to the Mayo Clinic.  Doctors at Mayo are significantly involved in prostate cryo-surgeries, doing about 500 such surgeries each year.  Furthermore, this type of surgery now has an insurance code, moving it from research to a standard medical practice. 

Based on the outcomes outlined above, we are excited about the potential for our technology to significantly improve both laser-ablation and cryo-ablation surgeries. We believe it will provide accurate temperature monitoring during the surgeries, thereby allowing for more accuracy, less surgical time, and better health outcomes for patients.  This will be the focus of our Phase II proposal.
